debrief.title: What Just Happened? Understanding Predatory Lending
debrief.introduction: You've just experienced a simulation of a real payday loan application. Let's break down the manipulative tactics you encountered and why they're so effective.

statistics_overview.title: The Payday Loan Industry in 2025
statistics_overview.content: The payday loan industry continues to thrive by exploiting financial vulnerability:

stats.label: Rollover Rate
stats.context: 4 out of 5 loans are rolled over or renewed

stats.label: Data Value
stats.context: Per application sold to data brokers

patterns.name: Bait and Switch
patterns.description: Started with '3 simple steps' but actually had 15+ steps
patterns.impact: Once started, people feel obligated to complete

patterns.name: Drip Pricing
patterns.impact: By the time full cost is known, users are invested

patterns.name: Social Proof Manipulation
patterns.description: Fake notifications of others getting approved
patterns.impact: Makes risky decision seem normal and safe

patterns.name: Confirmshaming
patterns.impact: Makes declining feel like losing money

patterns.name: Privacy Zuckering
patterns.description: Pre-checked boxes for data sharing, ACH access
patterns.impact: Users unknowingly agree to extensive permissions

kantian_ethics_violations.title: Violations of Informed Consent
kantian_ethics_violations.introduction: According to Kantian ethics, true consent requires:

requirements.violation: Critical terms hidden until final steps
requirements.example: 391% APR only shown at the end

requirements.violation: True cost and debt trap risk obscured

kantian_ethics_violations.conclusion: These violations mean borrowers cannot give genuine informed consent, making the practice fundamentally unethical.

stages.techniques: Vulnerability scoring, desperation detection, capacity assessment

stages.buyers: Other lenders, debt collectors, data brokers

stages.uses: Time collections, target marketing, social pressure

quiz.title: Test Your Understanding
quiz.instructions: Based on your experience in Phase 1, answer these questions to check your understanding of predatory lending tactics.

questions.question: What was the actual APR (Annual Percentage Rate) of the loan you were offered?
questions.explanation: The loan had a 391% APR, typical for payday loans. This was hidden until the final steps.

questions.question: Why did the application start with just 'name, phone, and ZIP code'?
options: To create psychological commitment before revealing complexity
To save time in the application process
questions.explanation: This is the 'foot in the door' technique. Once you start, you're more likely to continue even as requirements escalate.

questions.question: What percentage of payday loan borrowers end up rolling over their loans?
questions.explanation: 80% of payday loans are rolled over or renewed, creating a debt trap that generates most lender profits.

questions.question: According to Kantian ethics, why can't desperate borrowers give true consent?
questions.explanation: Kant argued that true consent requires freedom from coercion. Financial desperation is a form of coercion that prevents rational choice.

questions.question: What was the purpose of collecting your employer information and references?
options: To enable aggressive debt collection later
questions.explanation: References and employer info are primarily used for debt collection, including contacting and potentially embarrassing you.

questions.question: How much can lenders make by selling your application data?
questions.explanation: Your application data is worth $15-30 to other lenders and data brokers, sometimes exceeding the profit from the loan itself.

questions.question: What psychological principle makes fake countdown timers effective?
questions.explanation: Countdown timers exploit our fear of missing out (FOMO) and create artificial scarcity, preventing careful consideration.

questions.question: Why were expensive add-ons like 'loan insurance' pre-checked?
options: To exploit default bias - people rarely uncheck boxes
questions.explanation: Pre-checked boxes exploit default bias. Studies show most people don't uncheck boxes, even for unwanted services.

questions.question: What happens to the average payday loan borrower?
options: Pays back in 2 weeks as intended
Remains in debt for 5 months paying $520 in fees
questions.explanation: The average borrower remains in debt for 5 months and pays $520 in fees to borrow $375.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT a common payday loan loophole?
questions.explanation: Credit card processing isn't a loophole. Common loopholes include rent-a-bank, tribal lending, and open-end credit structures.

questions.question: What right do you have after taking a payday loan?
options: No rights - the contract is binding
Right to rescind within 1 business day
questions.explanation: Federal law gives you the right to cancel a payday loan within one business day without penalty.

questions.question: How do lenders use Plaid and bank account access?
options: To analyze spending and time collections for maximum impact
questions.explanation: Bank access lets lenders analyze your finances to time collections when you have money and identify all available funds.

ranges.message: You may be vulnerable to predatory lending. Please review the educational materials carefully.
ranges.recommendation: Focus on understanding APR, reading all terms, and recognizing manipulation tactics.

ranges.message: You have some awareness but could still fall victim to sophisticated tactics.
ranges.recommendation: Pay special attention to psychological manipulation and hidden terms.

ranges.message: Good understanding! You recognize most predatory tactics.
ranges.recommendation: Share your knowledge with others who might be vulnerable.

ranges.message: Excellent! You fully understand predatory lending tactics.
ranges.recommendation: Consider becoming an advocate for financial literacy in your community.

prompts.question: At what point in the application did you feel committed to completing it, even as red flags appeared?
prompts.insight: This reveals how commitment bias works against us.

prompts.question: Did the countdown timer or 'limited spots' message affect your reading of the terms?
prompts.insight: Time pressure is designed to bypass critical thinking.

prompts.question: How did you feel when you saw the final cost? Why didn't you see it sooner?
prompts.insight: Drip pricing exploits our tendency to focus on sunk costs.

prompts.question: Would you have given your employer info and references if asked upfront?
prompts.insight: Progressive disclosure gets us to share more than we normally would.
